Cheesy Mashed Potatoes

Jump to Recipe

Indulge in the ultimate comfort food with our Cheesy Mashed Potatoes recipe that combines the creamy goodness of traditional mashed potatoes with the rich flavor of melted cheddar cheese. Perfectly fluffy and bursting with cheesy flavor, this dish is not only easy to prepare but is also a crowd-pleaser that pairs wonderfully with any main course. Whether you're hosting a holiday gathering or simply looking for a delicious side dish for weeknight dinners, these cheesy mashed potatoes are sure to become a family favorite. Made with just a handful of simple ingredients like butter, milk, and fresh potatoes, this recipe showcases how a few elements can come together to create a warm, satisfying dish. Get ready to elevate your dining experience with these mouthwatering cheesy mashed potatoes that will have everyone coming back for seconds!

Ingredients

potatoes

Choose starchy potatoes like Russet or Yukon Gold for the best texture. For a creamier mash, avoid waxy potatoes like Red Bliss. If you're short on time, you can use pre-peeled and chopped frozen potatoes. Always rinse the potatoes after peeling to remove excess starch.

butter

Use unsalted butter for better control of seasoning. If you're looking for a richer flavor, try using European-style butter, which has a higher fat content. For a dairy-free option, substitute with olive oil or a plant-based butter.

milk

Whole milk will give you the creamiest texture, but you can substitute with half-and-half for an even richer result. For a non-dairy option, almond milk or soy milk can be used, though it may alter the flavor slightly.

cheddar cheese (shredded)

Sharp cheddar will provide a more intense flavor, while mild cheddar will be creamier. You can mix different types of cheese like Gruyère or Parmesan for added depth. If you want a lower-fat option, use reduced-fat cheddar.

salt

Start with a small amount of salt and adjust to taste. Using kosher salt or sea salt can enhance the flavor better than table salt. Always taste the potatoes after mashing to ensure the seasoning is balanced.

pepper

Freshly ground black pepper will provide the best flavor. For a twist, try adding white pepper for a milder taste or crushed red pepper flakes for a hint of heat. Adjust the amount based on your spice preference.

Cooking Steps

  • Step 1: Prepare the Potatoes

    Start by peeling 2 lbs of potatoes. Use a vegetable peeler for a clean peel. After peeling, chop the potatoes into even chunks, about 1-2 inches in size. This will ensure they cook uniformly.

  • Step 2: Boil the Potatoes

    Place the chopped potatoes into a large pot and cover them with cold water. Add a generous pinch of salt. Bring the water to a boil over medium-high heat. Once boiling, reduce to a simmer and cook for about 15-20 minutes, or until the potatoes are fork-tender. This means they should be soft enough to easily pierce with a fork.

  • Step 3: Drain and Return to Pot

    Carefully drain the potatoes using a colander and return them to the pot. This allows any excess moisture to evaporate, which is crucial for creamy mashed potatoes.

  • Step 4: Add Butter and Milk

    To the drained potatoes, add 4 tablespoons of butter and 1/2 cup of milk. The butter should be at room temperature to melt easily. If you prefer, you can warm the milk slightly to help everything combine smoothly.

  • Step 5: Mash the Potatoes

    Using a potato masher or a hand mixer, mash the potatoes until they reach your desired consistency. For creamy mashed potatoes, mash until smooth and fluffy, ensuring there are no lumps.

  • Step 6: Season and Add Cheese

    Season the mashed potatoes with salt and pepper to taste. Start with about 1/2 teaspoon of salt and a few cracks of black pepper. Then, stir in 1 cup of shredded cheddar cheese. Mix well until the cheese is melted and evenly distributed throughout the potatoes.

Frequently Asked Questions

What type of potatoes should I use for mashed potatoes?

For the best texture, use starchy potatoes like Russets or Yukon Golds. They become fluffy when mashed and absorb butter and milk well.

How can I tell when the potatoes are done boiling?

Potatoes are done when you can easily pierce them with a fork. The fork should slide in without much resistance.

Is it important to peel the potatoes?

Peeling is optional! Leaving the skins on can add texture and nutrients, but if you prefer a smoother mash, peel them before cooking.

How do I avoid gluey mashed potatoes?

To prevent gluey potatoes, don’t over-mash. Use a potato masher or ricer and stop once everything is combined and creamy.

What can I do if my mashed potatoes are too thick?

If your mashed potatoes are too thick, gradually add more milk, a tablespoon at a time, until you reach your desired consistency.

How can I make my mashed potatoes more flavorful?

Add ingredients like garlic, sour cream, or cream cheese for extra flavor. You can also experiment with herbs like chives or parsley.

What’s the best way to store leftover mashed potatoes?

Store leftover mashed potatoes in an airtight container in the fridge for up to 3 days. Reheat gently in the microwave or on the stove, adding a splash of milk if needed.

Can I make mashed potatoes ahead of time?

Yes! You can prepare them ahead and store them in the fridge. Reheat gently, and stir in a bit of milk or butter to restore creaminess.

What kitchen tools do I need to make mashed potatoes?

You’ll need a pot for boiling, a colander for draining, a potato masher or ricer for mashing, and a mixing spoon for combining ingredients.

How do I safely handle hot potatoes?

Use oven mitts or a thick kitchen towel to handle hot pots. Always be cautious when draining boiling potatoes—keep your face away from the steam!

Additional Information

Dietary Considerations

For a lighter version, substitute half of the potatoes with cauliflower. To make it dairy-free, use plant-based butter and almond milk, and opt for a dairy-free cheese alternative. If you're looking to reduce carbs, consider using sweet potatoes or a blend of sweet potatoes and regular potatoes for added flavor.

Pairings

Cheesy mashed potatoes pair wonderfully with roasted meats such as herb-crusted chicken, beef brisket, or a savory pork roast. For lighter options, consider grilled salmon or sautéed vegetables. For beverages, a full-bodied white wine like Chardonnay complements the creaminess of the potatoes, while a light red like Pinot Noir works well with meat dishes. A crisp apple cider is also a delightful non-alcoholic choice.

Serving Suggestions

Serve the cheesy mashed potatoes hot, ideally in a warm serving dish to maintain temperature. Garnish with a sprinkle of fresh chives or parsley for a pop of color and freshness. For a richer experience, drizzle some melted butter or add a dollop of sour cream on top before serving. Consider serving alongside a fresh garden salad to balance the richness of the dish.

Cheesy Mashed Potatoes

30 min
$5
300 kcal
Difficulty: 10%
Servings: 4

Allergens:

Dairy

Dietary Tags:

Vegetarian

Cuisine:

American

Course:

Side Dish

Tags:

EasyComfort FoodSide Dish

Description

Creamy, cheesy mashed potatoes that are simple to make and irresistibly delicious!

Ingredients

  • potatoes: 2 lbs
  • butter: 4 tbsp
  • milk: 1/2 cup
  • cheddar cheese (shredded): 1 cup
  • salt: to taste
  • pepper: to taste
